title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #215** is the Steinhaus Lattice Point Problem: Does there exist S ⊆ ℝ² such that every congruent copy of S contains exactly one point from ℤ²?

**Answer**: YES (Jackson-Mauldin 2002)

Erdős was 'almost certain' no such set exists, but the proof uses the Axiom of Choice.

title: Integer Lattice
content:
**integerLattice** is ℤ² embedded in EuclideanSpace ℝ (Fin 2).

A point p is in the lattice iff every coordinate is an integer: ∀ i, ∃ n : ℤ, p i = n.

title: Lattice Point Characterization
content:
A point is in **integerLattice** iff it satisfies **isLatticePoint**: there exist m, n : ℤ with p 0 = m and p 1 = n.

This gives two equivalent ways to express lattice membership.

title: Congruent Sets
content:
**IsCongruent S T** means T = f(S) for some isometry f.

In ℝ², isometries are compositions of translations, rotations, and reflections. This captures the notion of 'same shape and size'.

title: The Steinhaus Property
content:
**HasSteinhausProperty S** means every congruent copy of S meets ℤ² in exactly one point.

This is the key property Steinhaus asked about. Such a set S acts as a 'universal selector' for lattice points.

title: Counting Formulation
content:
The Steinhaus property is equivalent to: for every congruent copy T, **latticePointCount T = 1**.

This reformulation uses Set.ncard to count lattice points.

title: Jackson-Mauldin Theorem (Axiom)
content:
**jackson_mauldin_theorem**: There exists S with the Steinhaus property.

This is axiomatized because:
1. The proof requires the Axiom of Choice
2. The construction uses transfinite induction
3. No explicit description of S is possible

title: Main Result
content:
**erdos_215_answer**: The answer to Erdős Problem #215 is YES.

Such a set exists, proved by Jackson and Mauldin in 2002. The theorem follows directly from the axiom.

title: Steinhaus Sets are Unbounded
content:
**steinhaus_set_unbounded**: Any set with the Steinhaus property must be unbounded.

Intuitively, a bounded set would miss some lattice points when rotated appropriately.

title: Lattice Point Selector
content:
**steinhausSelector** extracts the unique lattice point from a congruent copy.

Given S with the Steinhaus property and any congruent T, we get the unique p ∈ T ∩ ℤ².

title: Higher Dimensional Generalization
content:
**jackson_mauldin_general**: The result generalizes to ℤⁿ ⊂ ℝⁿ for n ≥ 2.

The construction works in any dimension at least 2.
